item.title: Npc" AGRESSIVE!
item.dc:creator: @adog17x adog17x
item.description:
@adog17x wrote:

[quote=“LeScape, post:1, topic:195104”]Purpose: To make desired N.P.C.'s agressive towards players.
Difficulty: 2/10.
Tested: Yes.
Notes: None.
Procedures:
Step One
Alright, first we are going to add a method that will agrovate the N.P.C.'s in the class NPCHandler (NPCHandler.java). Here is mine:

public void agrovateNpcs() { //A method with no parameters and a void return type.
	for (int i : maxNPCs) { //A for-each loop going through all the N.P.C.'s on the server with the integer "i".
	}
}

A quick lesson on the for-each loop. The for-each loop goes through every item in an array with the value of the assigned integer being equal to the current item being gone through in the array. In this case, the array “maxNPCs” contains all of the N.P.C.'s on the server. The for-each loop goes through every N.P.C. on the server with the value of the integer i, which we will use to control the N.P.C.'s.

Step Two
Now we will create a method in the class client (client.java) that will determine if the given N.P.C.'s are agressive to the player or not by returning true or false. Create a new method, like so:

public boolean willBeAgressed() { //A method with a boolean return type and no parameters.
	return false; //Default return.
}

Inside this method you can put conditions you want the N.P.C.'s to be agressive to. Here’s an example of a simple return for the value of coordinates:

public boolean willBeAgressed() {
	if (absX >= 1000 && absY >= 1000 && absX <= 1500 && absY <= 1500) { //Checks to see if the player is in given coordinates.
		return true; //If the player is in the given coordinates, the boolean returns true.
	}
	return false; //Default return.
}

Now, you can put anything you like as the condition to return true. Thinks like: other booleans, integer values, etc. Here are a few more examples you could use:

public boolean willBeAgressed() {
	if (integerName == 1) { //Checks the value of an integer.
		return true; //Returns true.
	}
	return false;
}
public boolean willBeAgressed() {
	if (booleanName == true) { //Checks the status of a boolean.
		return true; //Returns true.
	}
	return false;
}

Step Three
Alright, back to the class NPCHandler. We’re going to add to the method we added in step one. Above the for-each loop, you’re going to add this:

	for (Player p : server.playerHandler.players) { //Another for-each loop, but this one goes through the players.
		client person = (client) p; //Will be used to reference the specific player being checked.

As well as a new closing bracket at the end of the method:

}

So your method should now look like this:

ublic void agrovateNpcs() {
	for (Player p : server.playerHandler.players) { //Newly added for-each loop.
		client person = (client) p; //Newly added declaration of client "person".
		for (int i : maxNPCs) {
		}
	} //New closing bracket for the for-each loop.
}

Step Four
Again, we are going to add even more to the method we added in step one. Inside of the for-each loop that checks N.P.C.'s (the second one), add this:

			if (person.willBeAgressed()) { //Checks to see if the method we added in step two is true.
			}

So your method should now look like this:

public void agrovateNpcs() {
	for (Player p : server.playerHandler.players) {
		client person = (client) p;
		for (int i : maxNPCs) {
			if (person.willBeAgressed()) { //Newly added if-then block.
			}
		}
	}
}

Steo Five
Yet ANOTHER motification to the method we added in step one. Inside the if-then block, add this:

				if (person != null) { //Makes sure that the person is not a null.
					if (npcs[i] != null) { //Same as above, but for the N.P.C.
					}
				}

So your method should now look like this:

public void agrovateNpcs() {
	for (Player p : server.playerHandler.players) {
		client person = (client) p;
		for (int i : maxNPCs) {
			if (person.willBeAgressed()) {
				if (person != null) { //Newly added if-then block.
					if (npcs[i] != null) { //Newly added if-then block.
					}
				}
			}
		}
	}
}

Step Five
Now I am going to make a N.P.C. agressive to show you how this works. Inside the third if-then block in our agrovateNpcs() method, I’m going to add this:

						if (npcs[i].npcType == 2745) { //Checks to see if the npc is TzTok-Jad (2745).
							npcs[i].StartKilling = person.playerId; //It is, so it proceeds to make TzTok-Jad attack the player.
							npcs[i].RandomWalk = false; //Stops TzTok-Jad from walking randomly.
							npcs[i].IsUnderAttack = true; //Says that TzTok-Jad is under attack.
							npcs[i].followPlayer = person.playerId; //Makes TzTok-Jad follow the player so that the player cannot run away.
						}

Making the method look like this:

public void agrovateNpcs() {
	for (Player p : server.playerHandler.players) {
		client person = (client) p;
		for (int i : maxNPCs) {
			if (person.willBeAgressed()) {
				if (person != null) {
					if (npcs[i] != null) {
						if (npcs[i].npcType == 2745) {
							npcs[i].StartKilling = person.playerId;
							npcs[i].RandomWalk = false;
							npcs[i].IsUnderAttack = true;
							npcs[i].followPlayer = person.playerId;
						}
					}
				}
			}
		}
	}
}

Step Six
Now, inside the public void process in the class NPCHandler, I’m going to call the method we’ve been modifying all this time, like so:

agrovateNpcs(); //Calling our method.

Now TzTok-Jad will be agressive to any player who’s willBeAgressed() method returns true.

Step Seven
To add a new agression, simple add a new block of this:

						if (npcs[i].npcType == #) { //Replace # with the identification number of the N.P.C. you want to be agressive.
							npcs[i].StartKilling = person.playerId;
							npcs[i].RandomWalk = false;
							npcs[i].IsUnderAttack = true;
							npcs[i].followPlayer = person.playerId;
						}

That would be added above or underneath the block I added in step five.

Terms To Remember:
For-each loop: Goes through every item in an array with the value of the assigned integer being equal to the current item being gone through in the array.

Credits: Me.[/quote]
